questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is not a hypoproliferative anemia?
questions.explanation:
Hemolytic anemia is not a hypoproliferative anemia. Anemia can be defined as hemoglobin of < 13 g/dl in men and < 12 g/dl in women. Based on 
the mechanism of reduction of hemoglobin, anemia can be classified as: • Hypoproliferative anemias - due to impaired production of RBCs • Hemolytic anemias and hemoglobinopathies - due to increased destruction of RBCs • Anemia due to blood loss Hypoproliferative anemias are characterized by an abnormally low reticulocyte 
response (reticulocyte index <2–2.5) to reduced RBC production. They include: • Iron-deficiency anemia • Anemia of chronic disease (inflammation, renal disease, or malignancies) • Thalassemia • Sideroblastic anemia • Aplastic anemia • Megaloblastic macrocytic anemias (folate and vitamin B12 deficiency) • Non-megaloblastic macrocytic anemias (alcohol use)

questions.question:
Question 2: A 25-year-old woman came to the OPD one year after the birth of her last child. She had been 
treated for iron deficiency anemia while pregnant. On examination, she is pale and 
investigations show a Hb of 5g/dl and a reticulocyte count of 9%. What is her corrected 
reticulocyte count? (Take normal Hb as 15g/dl)
questions.explanation:
The corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) of this patient is 3. CRC = Reticulocyte % x (Actual Hb / Normal Hb) Plugging in the values given in the question, CRC = 9% x 5/15 = 3% Alternatively, CRC can be calculated using hematocrit (PCV) as follows: CRC = Reticulocyte % x (Actual PCV / Normal PCV) For these calculations, take normal Hb as 15g/dL and normal PCV as 45%. The patient's hemoglobin level (5 g/dL) is significantly lower than the normal hemoglobin level (15 
g/dL). To obtain an accurate assessment of reticulocyte production relative to the reduced number 
of circulating red blood cells, a correction factor has to be applied. CRC accounts for the anemia 
and provides a more precise estimate of the reticulocyte count. When polychromatophilic macrocytes (prematurely released reticulocytes/shift cells) are observed 
in the peripheral blood smear, a second correction is applied to account for the longer life of 
reticulocytes to yield reticulocyte production index (RPI). 1285 
Sold by @itachibot In the classification of anemia, the patient's reticulocyte count is compared to the expected 
reticulocyte response. Reticulocytes can be identified by staining their ribosomal RNA with a 
supravital dye, resulting in the formation of blue or black punctate spots. They can be quantified 
manually or by using fluorescent dyes. The presence of reticulocytes indicates active red cell 
production. The premature release of reticulocytes is typically associated with increased EPO stimulation. In 
hemolytic anemia, red cell production can increase six to seven times. If the RPI < 2 in a patient 
with anemia, a defect in erythroid marrow proliferation or maturation has to be suspected.

questions.question: Question 3: What does the red cell distribution width deal with?
questions.explanation:
Red cell distribution width (RDW) measures the range of red blood cell volumes and provides an 
assessment of their variability (anisocytosis). The normal range of RDW is 11-14%. In the presence of uneven cell size (anisocytosis), the RDW 
increases to 15-18%. RDW has clinical utility in two main scenarios: • In cases of microcytic anemia (low MCV), it helps differentiate between iron deficiency and 
thalassemia. Thalassemia is characterized by uniformly small red blood cells with a normal RDW, 
while iron deficiency leads to greater size variability and an increased RDW. • A high RDW can indicate dimorphic anemia caused by chronic atrophic gastritis. Vitamin B12 
malabsorption results in macrocytic anemia and blood loss leads to iron deficiency (microcytic 
anemia).

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following patients is unlikely to have the following finding on a peripheral smear 
study? 1276 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: A 55-year-old alcoholic man with ascites and jaundice
options.b: A 19-year-old girl who underwent emergency splenectomy after a road accident
options.c: A 25-year-old man with hemoglobin C disease
options.d: A 70-year-old woman undergoing dialysis for the past 3 years

questions.explanation:
The black arrows in the given image denote target cells or codocytes. They are RBCs with a dense 
center (hyperchromic bull's eye) surrounded by an area of pallor. They are not a feature of renal 
disease (Patient D). Target cells are seen in the following conditions: • Thalassemia • Iron deficiency anemia • Liver disease • Post-splenectomy • Hemoglobin C disease • As artifacts in improperly prepared slides

questions.question:
Question 5: A first-year pathology resident prepares the following smear from a patient's blood sample. 
Which of the following is it suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
1286 
Sold by @itachibot The small, dense RBCs with absent central pallor seen in the given peripheral smear are 
called spherocytes. They appear due to decreased membrane surface area and are seen in the 
following conditions: • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia • Hereditary spherocytosis • Clostridial sepsis • Snake bites

questions.question: Question 6: The following finding is not typically seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
The given peripheral smear shows teardrop cells or dacrocytes. They are not seen in sideroblastic 
anemia. Teardrop cells are seen in the following conditions: • Myelofibrosis • Myelodysplastic syndromes • Hemolytic anemia • Thalassemia • Severe iron deficiency

questions.question:
Question 7: The following blood picture is seen in patients with which of the following conditions? 1278 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows Howell-Jolly bodies. They are remnants of RBC nuclei that occur in 
conditions with either defective production (dysplasia) or destruction of RBCs. They are observed 
in the following conditions: • Sickle cell disease (postsplenectomy) • Hyposplenism • Megaloblastic anemia • Dyshematopoesis • Hemolytic anemia Thalassemia presents with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, and target cells. Lead poisoning presents with basophilic stippling or punctate basophilia on peripheral smears. 
These are RNA fragments seen as numerous basophilic granules dispersed in the cytoplasm of 
RBCs, as shown below. 1287 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 30-year-old man with a BMI of 41 kg/m2 is being evaluated for bariatric surgery. Which of 
the following procedures does not reduce the surface area for iron absorption?
questions.explanation:
Iron absorption takes place in the duodenum. In sleeve gastrectomy, a portion of the stomach is 
resected but the duodenum remains intact. Hence, the surface area of iron absorption is not 
affected. Dietary iron is efficiently absorbed in its heme form. Non-heme iron is less efficiently absorbed 
mainly because of interference by phosphates, tannins, oxalates, and other food constituents. 
Acidic pH enhances iron absorption by promoting the conversion of ferric to ferrous iron by the 
enzyme ferrireductase. 1288 
Sold by @itachibot The following are malabsorptive procedures that reduce the duodenal surface area and hence, 
reduce iron absorption: • Biliopancreatic diversion • Roux-en-Y gastric bypass • Duodenal switch

questions.question:
Question 9: You have prescribed oral iron supplements for an anemic young woman. Which of the 
following foods should she avoid taking along with these supplements?
questions.explanation:
Tea contains tannins, which inhibit iron absorption. Hence, it should not be taken with iron 
supplements. Iron absorption is also reduced by: • Calcium supplements and antacids • Milk and dairy products • Proton pump inhibitors Grapefruit and kiwi are acid-containing citrus fruits that create an acidic pH and hence, increase 
iron absorption. Broccoli contains ascorbic acid that also enhances iron absorption.

questions.question: Question 10: The levels of which of the following will be detected first in a patient with iron deficiency?
questions.explanation:
The earliest sign of iron deficiency is a decrease in serum ferritin levels. This is called the state of 
negative iron balance. Iron deficiency anemia develops in 3 stages: • Stage of negative iron balance - decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC 
morphology 1289 
Sold by @itachibot • Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC 
morphology • Stage of iron deficiency anemia - fall in hemoglobin with microcytic hypochromic RBCs

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following is not seen in the stage of negative iron balance in iron-deficiency 
anemia?
questions.explanation:
TIBC (total iron-binding capacity) does not decrease during the stage of a negative iron balance of 
iron deficiency anemia. The progression to iron deficiency develops in 3 stages: • Stage of negative iron balance - Decrease in iron stores with normal serum iron and RBC 
morphology • Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - Decrease in serum iron levels with normal RBC 
morphology • Stage of iron deficiency anemia - Microcytic hypochromic RBCs Iron-deficient erythropoiesis

questions.question: Question 12: Patients with which of the following do not need to be evaluated for iron deficiency?

options.a: Unusual craving to eat clay and paper
options.b: Insomnia due to a compulsive urge to keep moving the legs
options.c: Incidental finding of esophageal webs on upper GI endoscopy
options.d: Tingling and numbness of lower extremities

questions.explanation:
Tingling and numbness of the lower extremities are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. It is a 
feature of vitamin B12 deficiency, not iron deficiency. Iron-deficiency anemia is associated with the following findings: • Smooth tongue - due to loss of papillae • Cheilosis - fissuring at corners of mouth • Brittle nails • Koilonychia - spooning of nails • Pica - craving for non-edible foods like ice chips, hair, paper, clay 1290 
Sold by @itachibot • Plummer–Vinson syndrome - dysphagia due to the formation of esophageal webs • Restless legs syndrome - compulsive urge to keep moving the legs which results in insomnia

questions.question:
Question 13: Which of the following PBF findings is least likely to be seen in patients with iron deficiency 
anemia? 1280 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Image 4 shows dense RBCs with loss of central pallor or spherocytes. They are seen in 
autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and hereditary spherocytosis, not iron deficiency anemia. The peripheral blood smear in iron deficiency anemia shows: • Microcytic hypochromic cells • Target cells • Pencil-shaped or cigar-shaped cells • Poikilocytosis- variations in the shape of RBCs • Anisocytosis- variations in the size of RBCs.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the ER after she faints at home. Her husband says that 
she is very body-conscious and does intermittent fasting. She has been on a vegan diet for the 
past 2 months. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iron deficiency anemia due to the following findings: • Low MCV (N: 87-96 fL) • Low MCH (N: 27-33 pg) • Elevated RDW • High TIBC Option A: Anemia of chronic disease is associated with low TIBC. 1291 
Sold by @itachibot Options B and D: Anemia due to B12 and folate deficiency presents with a high MCV 
(macrocytosis).

questions.question:
Question 15: A 62-year-old woman is found to have a Hb of 7.2 g/dl and high ferritin levels. She has been 
undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer since last year. Which of the following is 
responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease. The chief mediator of this 
condition is hepcidin. Anemia of chronic disease is associated with chronic inflammatory states such as inflammatory 
bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, and malignancies. Hepcidin is a positive acute-phase reactant (ARP) that increases in chronic inflammatory states. It 
binds with ferroportin which results in both reduced iron intake in the gut and reduced iron 
transfer from macrophages to erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow. Hence, hepcidin is 
a negative regulator of iron balance.

questions.question: Question 16: Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in patients with which of the following?
questions.explanation: Normocytic normochromic anemia is seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is also seen in the following conditions: • RBC membrane disorders - hereditary spherocytosis, elliptocytosis • RBC enzyme disorders - G6PD deficiency, Pyruvate kinase deficiency • Parvovirus B19 infection • Anemia of chronic disease - can also present as microcytic anemia

questions.question:
Question 17: A 38-year-old woman presented to the OPD with progressive tiredness over the last 2 
months. She also reported having heavy menstrual bleeding during her previous 2 cycles. She 
is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. Lab investigations are given below. What is the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of anemia of chronic disease due to the following findings: • Low MCV (N: 87-96 fl) • Low TIBC (N: 300-360g/dL) • Elevated ferritin level (N: 50-200 g/L) • Normal transferrin saturation (N: 25-50%)

questions.question:
Question 18: A 60-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis is found to have a 
hemoglobin of 6.3 mg/dl. Which of the following will be additionally seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Anemia of CKD is a form of hypoproliferative anemia presenting with decreased reticulocytes. It mainly occurs due to a failure of erythropoietin production by the diseased kidney and a 
reduction in the survival of RBCs. Also, patients with CKD maintained on chronic hemodialysis 1292 
Sold by @itachibot may develop iron deficiency from blood loss through the dialysis procedure. The following features are seen: • Normocytic and normochromic RBCs • Decreased reticulocytes • Serum iron, transferrin saturation, TIBC are usually normal or low • Decreased serum ferritin The degree of anemia usually correlates with the severity of the renal failure. Note: Anaemia in CKD is not the same as anaemia of chronic disease.

questions.question: Question 19: What is the predominant inheritance pattern of sideroblastic anemia?
questions.explanation:
Inherited forms of sideroblastic anemia are usually X-linked. Rarely, autosomal recessive forms 
may also occur. X- linked sideroblastic anemia results from the deficient activity of the erythroid form of 
ALA-synthase (ALA-synthase 2) and is associated with ineffective erythropoiesis

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia?
questions.explanation: High serum iron levels are seen in patients with sideroblastic anemia. Sideroblastic anemia presents with the following features: • Serum iron level - high/normal • Transferrin saturation - high • Serum ferritin levels - high • TIBC - low/normal • Peripheral smear - dimorphic population (both microcytes and macrocytes). • Bone marrow study - marked erythroid hyperplasia. The iron profile of sideroblastic anemia is opposite to that of iron deficiency anemia.

questions.question:
Question 21: The bone marrow biopsy sample of a patient with chronic anemia is stained with Prussian 
blue, as shown below. The stained deposits are present in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows ringed sideroblasts, which are erythroid precursors in the marrow. In 
these cells, iron deposits in the mitochondria form a ring around the nucleus and are stained by 
Prussian blue. The mature red blood cell counterparts of ringed sideroblasts in the circulation are called 
siderocytes. These cells have iron-containing basophilic granules called Pappenheimer bodies, as 1293 
Sold by @itachibot shown below. Ringed sideroblasts and Pappenheimer bodies are pathognomonic of sideroblastic anemia.

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following drugs is known to cause sideroblastic anemia?
questions.explanation:
Chloramphenicol is known to cause sideroblastic anemia. The agents known to cause sideroblastic anemia are: • Isoniazid • Chloramphenicol • Linezolid • Excessive alcohol 1294 
Sold by @itachibot Macrocytic Anemia
